episode_title: Entrepreneur's Guide to Real Estate Investing
transcript:
ï»¿Nikolas Hulewsky (00:00.894)
All right, welcome back to Nick economics. I've got Robert Leonard with me who is a real estate entrepreneur. He's done over a dozen real estate transactions, but I think the coolest thing that I like about him is he's had a podcast with over 15 million downloads, teaching people the stuff that we're about to talk to talk about today, which is getting into real estate as entrepreneurs. Robert, I'm stoked to have you. You're in New Hampshire, right?


Robert (00:24.545)
I am, I am.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:26.12)
Okay. I think there's this funny thing in entrepreneurship where we as entrepreneurs look at guys like you who are like, man, it must be fricking nice to have just a portfolio of real estate assets, just collecting that passive income, bro. I want to do that. But then I've known guys like you who are on the other end of the coin. They're like, man, it must be nice to have an SMB with no capped upside where I'm like, I got cashflow and I'm building real asset value in this enterprise. So there's kind of like a grass is greener.


on both sides of the equation, having been on both sides of it, which grass do you think is greener?


Robert (01:01.408)
It depends where you are in the journey. think if you're early on in the journey, the SMB path is greener. If you're a little bit further along, I think the real estate path is greener. And we can dive into that a little bit more in the journey, but yeah, that's what I think. If you're early-ish on in your journey, I think the SMB route or just any entrepreneurial venture is the better route, the greener route. And then real estate is greener a little bit later on.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:25.63)
Mm-hmm.


Why? Let's talk about that.


Robert (01:30.88)
It takes money. It just it does. Like there's a lot of stuff out like there are a lot of strategies and sure there are some people who have done some like really creative stuff through wholesaling and subject to and some other stuff that you can do that can get really creative to get some deals with little capital. And you can snowball that by getting one or two deals and then tapping into the equity and.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:53.726)
You

putting that into two or three more deals. And so it can be done. I'm not saying it can't be done, but ultimately you'll just have a lot better experience in real estate if you do have some capital, generally speaking, if you want that to be like your real income generator and versus on the other side, like a business or SMB or any type of entrepreneurial venture, whether it's a side hustle or a real startup, it can be done with a lot less capital, especially these days. So I think that that's why.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:09.875)
Yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:20.542)
Totally. I had Chris Berg on my podcast a little while back and he's an entrepreneur. had an e-commerce business, was kicking off a bunch of cash. So I agree with you like down the road when you have some cash.


it's nicer to funnel money into real estate. Whereas in the beginning, you don't have cash, you're just trying to get in the game. So starting a small business doesn't really require you to go out and raise $100 million. You could start a small business with a hundred bucks or for nothing if you know what you're doing.


Robert (03:07.564)
Yeah, exactly. And that's my exact approach is make the money in a side hustle or a business and then or even your job and then put that into real estate once you have enough. Nikolas Hulewsky (03:30.066)

Well, I've seen a lot of guys who were like, they're trying to get into real estate. Real estate is amazing, right?
